questions.text: Light pencil is acceptable for Exam 1 if your handwriting is neat.
questions.explanation: Papers are scanned for marking. Light pencil and faint lines often don't scan clearly. Use dark blue/black pen or 2B pencil minimum.
questions.studyTip: Dark ink or 2B pencil—assessors mark scanned images, not your paper.

questions.text: Faint dashed lines for asymptotes may not be detected when papers are scanned.
questions.explanation: Asymptotes drawn too lightly can disappear in scanning. Make all lines, including dashed ones, dark enough to be visible.
questions.studyTip: Draw asymptotes darker than you think necessary. If they can't see it, they can't mark it.

questions.text: For multi-mark questions, a correct final answer without working earns full marks.
questions.explanation: Where more than one mark is available, appropriate working must be shown. A correct answer alone won't earn method marks.
questions.studyTip: No working = no marks, even if the answer is right.

questions.text: Showing your method step-by-step allows you to earn partial marks even with calculation errors.
questions.explanation: Method marks reward correct approach. A small arithmetic slip with good working still earns most marks.
questions.studyTip: Write every step. Partial credit comes from visible method.

questions.text: If you use extra working space, you can leave multiple possible answers for the assessor to choose from.
questions.explanation: If multiple conflicting final answers are presented, full marks cannot be awarded. Your intended answer must be clearly identifiable.
questions.studyTip: Box your final answer. One clear answer, not multiple attempts.

questions.text: When using extra working space, your final answer must be clearly marked as your intended response.
questions.explanation: Assessors must know which answer you want marked. Circle or underline your final response.
questions.studyTip: Scratch out wrong attempts. Make your final answer unmistakable.

questions.text: When sketching graphs in pencil, lightly crossing out errors is sufficient.
questions.explanation: Unintended sketches must be erased thoroughly. Crossed-out work can confuse assessors about your intended answer.
questions.studyTip: Erase completely. If both graphs show, which one gets marked?

questions.text: Graph sketches should be in pencil so errors can be fully erased if needed.
questions.explanation: Pencil allows clean corrections. Just ensure your final graph is dark enough to scan.
questions.studyTip: Pencil for graphs, pen for working. Erase errors completely.

concepts.title: No CAS means manual skills matter

questions.text: Exam 1 allows basic calculators, so arithmetic errors are rare.
questions.explanation: Exam 1 has no technology or notes. All differentiation, integration, and algebra must be done by hand. Errors are common.
questions.studyTip: Practise without CAS. Exam 1 tests your manual computation skills.

questions.text: Exam 1 requires strong manual algebra and arithmetic since no technology is permitted.
questions.explanation: You must differentiate, integrate, and manipulate expressions by hand. Practise these skills thoroughly.
questions.studyTip: Drill derivatives, integrals, and algebra by hand before Exam 1.

questions.text: As long as your mathematics is correct, messy handwriting won't affect your marks.
questions.explanation: Illegible digits, unclear notation, or ambiguous symbols can cost marks. Assessors must be able to read your work.
questions.studyTip: Clear digits, clear symbols. If they can't read it, they can't mark it.

questions.text: Taking care with digit formation prevents misreading of numbers like 4 and 9, or 1 and 7.
questions.explanation: Similar-looking digits cause misreading. One wrong digit means a wrong answer.
questions.studyTip: Slow down for final answers. A misread digit ruins your mark.

questions.text: HB pencil is too light for Exam 2 responses.
questions.explanation: HB or darker pencil is acceptable, as is dark blue or black pen. Just ensure your writing is dark enough to scan clearly.
questions.studyTip: HB minimum for pencil. Dark blue or black ink works best.

questions.text: Using a HB or darker pencil, or dark pen, ensures your work scans clearly for assessors.
questions.explanation: Papers are scanned for marking. Dark writing reproduces reliably; faint writing may be missed.
questions.studyTip: Test your pen before the exam. If it's fading, replace it.

questions.text: Decimal approximations are always acceptable if they're accurate to several decimal places.
questions.explanation: Unless decimal places are specified, give exact answers. Writing 0.333 instead of ⅓ or 1.414 instead of √2 loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Exact form unless told otherwise. π stays as π, not 3.14.

questions.text: You must give exact values like √2 or π unless the question specifies decimal places.
questions.explanation: This is explicitly stated in exam instructions. Only round when explicitly told to.
questions.studyTip: Check: does it say 'correct to 2 decimal places'? If not, stay exact.

questions.text: Brackets are optional when writing coordinates or intervals as long as the numbers are correct.
questions.explanation: Coordinates must have round brackets: (3, 5) not 3, 5. Interval notation requires correct bracket types. Missing brackets lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Coordinates: round brackets (a, b). Close every bracket you open.

questions.text: Writing coordinates without closing brackets, like (36, 5180, is incorrect notation.
questions.explanation: This error was commonly seen. Mathematical notation requires complete brackets.
questions.studyTip: (36, 5180 is wrong. (36, 5180) is right. Close your brackets.

questions.text: For the interval from 2 to 5 including both endpoints, [5, 2] and [2, 5] are equivalent.
questions.explanation: Interval notation requires the smaller value first: [2, 5] is correct, [5, 2] is wrong. Order matters.
questions.studyTip: Smaller value first in intervals. [a, b] means a < b.

questions.text: Square brackets [ ] mean endpoints are included; round brackets ( ) mean endpoints are excluded.
questions.explanation: This distinction is essential. Using round brackets when square are needed (or vice versa) is incorrect.
questions.studyTip: [includes], (excludes). Know when to use which.

questions.text: Copying answers from your CAS screen is straightforward and rarely causes errors.
questions.explanation: Transcription errors are common. Students misread displays, miss digits, add extra zeros, or copy wrong lines.
questions.studyTip: Read the CAS output twice before writing. One wrong digit ruins everything.

questions.text: Carefully checking when transferring answers from CAS to paper prevents common errors.
questions.explanation: Many marks are lost to transcription mistakes. Verify digits match before writing your final answer.
questions.studyTip: Copy slowly. Check each digit. Better slow and right than fast and wrong.

questions.text: If a question asks for 3 decimal places, giving 2 decimal places is close enough.
questions.explanation: You must give exactly the accuracy requested. Giving 2 decimal places when 3 are required loses marks.
questions.studyTip: 3 d.p. means 3 d.p. Count your decimal places.

questions.text: When a question specifies decimal places, you must give exactly that many.
questions.explanation: Set your CAS to display enough decimal places. Follow the instruction precisely.
questions.studyTip: Check your CAS settings. Make sure you can see enough decimal places.

questions.text: If you find the value asked for, you've completed the question.
questions.explanation: Students often answer only part of a question. Read carefully—if it asks for coordinates, give (x, y) not just x.
questions.studyTip: Re-read after answering. Did you give everything asked for?

questions.text: Re-reading questions after answering helps ensure you've addressed all required parts.
questions.explanation: Common errors: giving x instead of (x, y), finding a value but not the equation, missing 'd' in function parameters.
questions.studyTip: Question says 'find the equation'? Your answer must be an equation.

questions.text: If a question uses f(x), you can write y = instead of f'(x) = for the derivative.
questions.explanation: Use the function names given in the question. If it defines f(x), write f'(x) for the derivative, not y' or dy/dx.
questions.studyTip: Question uses f(x)? Your derivative is f'(x), not y'.

questions.text: Matching the function notation used in the question shows precise mathematical communication.
questions.explanation: If the question uses g(x), your answers should use g(x), g'(x), etc. Notation consistency matters.
questions.studyTip: Mirror their notation. f(x) → f'(x). g(x) → g'(x).

questions.text: Writing ∫f(x) without dx is acceptable shorthand.
questions.explanation: An integral must include the differential: ∫f(x)dx. Omitting dx is incorrect mathematical notation.
questions.studyTip: No dx, no integral. It's not optional.

questions.text: Every integral statement must include dx to indicate the variable of integration.
questions.explanation: The dx tells you what variable you're integrating with respect to. Always include it.
questions.studyTip: Write ∫f(x)dx every single time. Build the habit.

questions.text: Writing log(x) is the same as logₑ(x) in Mathematical Methods.
questions.explanation: The base must be explicit. Write logₑ(x) or ln(x), not just log(x). The base goes as a subscript.
questions.studyTip: Always show the base: logₑ(x) or ln(x). Never just log(x).

questions.text: The proper representation of a natural logarithm has the base e as a subscript: logₑ(x).
questions.explanation: Mathematical Methods uses logₑ(x) notation. Ensure the base is correctly positioned as a subscript.
questions.studyTip: logₑ(x) with e as subscript. Or use ln(x).

questions.text: When writing a cube root, the radical sign extends over the radicand without needing a small 3.
questions.explanation: The cube root requires a small 3 outside the radical symbol: ∛. Without it, you're writing a square root.
questions.studyTip: ∛x for cube root (small 3). √x for square root. They're different.

questions.text: Radicals must extend completely over the radicand, or brackets must surround it.
questions.explanation: √2x could mean √(2x) or (√2)x. Use brackets or extend the radical fully to avoid ambiguity.
questions.studyTip: √(2x) is clear. √2x is ambiguous. Use brackets.

questions.text: A short fraction line is fine as long as the numerator is clear.
questions.explanation: The vinculum (fraction line) must extend over the entire denominator. A short line creates ambiguity about what's in the fraction.
questions.studyTip: Fraction line must cover the whole denominator. No ambiguity allowed.

questions.text: Drawing the fraction line long enough to cover the entire denominator prevents misreading.
questions.explanation: A short vinculum can make 1/2x look like ½x instead of 1/(2x). Extend it fully.
questions.studyTip: When in doubt, make the fraction line longer. Add brackets if needed.

questions.text: The derivative of f(x)g(x) is simply f'(x)g'(x).
questions.explanation: The product rule states: (fg)' = f'g + fg'. You differentiate each function in turn while keeping the other unchanged.
questions.studyTip: Product rule: (uv)' = u'v + uv'. Two terms, not one.

questions.text: The product rule gives f'(x)g(x) + f(x)g'(x) for the derivative of a product.
questions.explanation: Each function takes a turn being differentiated while the other stays as is. Add the results.
questions.studyTip: Differentiate first × keep second + keep first × differentiate second.

questions.text: When differentiating (2x + 1)⁵, you only need to bring down the power: 5(2x + 1)⁴.
questions.explanation: The chain rule requires multiplying by the derivative of the inner function: 5(2x + 1)⁴ × 2 = 10(2x + 1)⁴.
questions.studyTip: Chain rule: multiply by derivative of inside. Don't forget that factor.

questions.text: The chain rule requires multiplying by the derivative of the inner function.
questions.explanation: For f(g(x)), the derivative is f'(g(x)) × g'(x). The 'inner derivative' is essential.
questions.studyTip: d/dx[f(g(x))] = f'(g(x)) × g'(x). Two parts, always.

questions.text: Leaving exponential terms like e⁻ˣ × eˣ unsimplified is acceptable in your final answer.
questions.explanation: Questions often require simplified answers. e⁻ˣ × eˣ = e⁰ = 1. Simplify where possible.
questions.studyTip: Simplify exponentials: e^a × e^b = e^(a+b). Clean up your final answer.

questions.text: Simplifying expressions, including combining exponential terms, gives cleaner final answers.
questions.explanation: Simplified answers show mathematical fluency. Collect like terms, simplify surds, combine exponentials.
questions.studyTip: Check: can this be simplified? eˣ × e²ˣ = e³ˣ.

questions.text: When applying the product rule, brackets around terms are optional.
questions.explanation: Missing brackets cause sign errors and incorrect grouping. Students often lose marks by not using brackets around product rule terms.
questions.studyTip: Brackets are your friends. More brackets = fewer errors.

questions.text: Using brackets when applying differentiation rules prevents sign errors and incorrect grouping.
questions.explanation: Writing (f'g) + (fg') is clearer than f'g + fg'. Brackets help you track terms correctly.
questions.studyTip: Add brackets around each term. Then simplify. Errors happen without them.

questions.text: To find turning points, you only need to solve f(x) = 0.
questions.explanation: Turning points occur where f'(x) = 0, not f(x) = 0. You must differentiate first, then solve.
questions.studyTip: Turning points: set the DERIVATIVE to zero, not the function.

questions.text: Finding turning points requires setting the derivative equal to zero and solving.
questions.explanation: f'(x) = 0 gives x-coordinates of turning points. Then substitute back to find y-coordinates.
questions.studyTip: f'(x) = 0 → solve for x → substitute into f(x) for y.

concepts.title: Instantaneous vs average rate of change

questions.text: Instantaneous rate of change and average rate of change are calculated the same way.
questions.explanation: Instantaneous rate = f'(a). Average rate = [f(b) - f(a)]/(b - a). Students commonly confuse these.
questions.studyTip: Instantaneous = derivative at a point. Average = slope between two points.

questions.text: The instantaneous rate of change is found by evaluating the derivative at a point.
questions.explanation: f'(a) gives the instantaneous rate of change at x = a. This is different from the average rate over an interval.
questions.studyTip: See 'instantaneous rate of change'? That means find f'(x) at that point.

questions.text: When finding area between curves, the order of subtraction doesn't matter.
questions.explanation: You must subtract correctly: ∫(top curve - bottom curve). Wrong order gives negative values or wrong answers.
questions.studyTip: Area = ∫(top - bottom). Check which curve is on top in your interval.

questions.text: Area between curves requires integrating (upper function - lower function) over the interval.
questions.explanation: ∫[f(x) - g(x)]dx where f is above g in the region. Check by testing a point.
questions.studyTip: Pick a test point in the interval. Which function is bigger there?

questions.text: If your integral gives a negative value for an area, you can just remove the negative sign.
questions.explanation: You need to show reasoning: either use absolute value notation, state 'area must be positive', or set up the integral correctly from the start.
questions.studyTip: Show WHY area is positive. Don't just drop the negative sign.

questions.text: When an integral for area gives a negative result, you must justify making it positive.
questions.explanation: Write |∫...| or state 'Area is positive, so...' to show you understand why the sign changes.
questions.studyTip: Integral negative? Write: 'Area = |result| = positive value.'

questions.text: When setting up a definite integral, you can use any reasonable x-values as limits.
questions.explanation: Terminals must match the problem context. Using x-intercepts when the question specifies x = 0 to x = 2 is wrong.
questions.studyTip: Read what the question says. Use exactly those limits.

questions.text: Integration limits must match exactly what the question specifies.
questions.explanation: Common error: using x-intercepts instead of given bounds. Read the question carefully.
questions.studyTip: Underline the limits in the question. Use those exact values.

questions.text: For questions worth multiple marks, you can use CAS to find bounded area without showing an integral.
questions.explanation: You must show relevant working. Write down the definite integral even if you use CAS to evaluate it.
questions.studyTip: Write the integral setup, THEN use CAS. Show the ∫...dx.

questions.text: Questions requiring bounded area should show the definite integral even when using CAS.
questions.explanation: The integral expression demonstrates your understanding. CAS just does the calculation.
questions.studyTip: Write: Area = ∫ₐᵇ (top - bottom) dx = [CAS result].

questions.text: To find the total area between curves that cross, you only need one integral.
questions.explanation: If curves cross, you need separate integrals for each region, or the areas may cancel out.
questions.studyTip: Curves cross? Split into regions. Integrate each separately.

questions.text: When curves cross within the interval, you need multiple integrals to find total area.
questions.explanation: At crossing points, which curve is on top changes. Handle each region separately.
questions.studyTip: Find intersection points. Set up separate integrals for each region.

questions.text: A rough sketch showing the general shape is sufficient for graph questions.
questions.explanation: Graphs must be accurate. Turning points, intercepts, and endpoints must be positioned precisely on the grid.
questions.studyTip: Use the grid. Plot key points exactly, then draw smooth curves through them.

questions.text: Graph sketches should have turning points and intercepts positioned accurately using the grid.
questions.explanation: The grid is provided to help accuracy. Use it to place features at correct coordinates.
questions.studyTip: Plot turning points first. Then draw the curve through them.

questions.text: Graphs of hyperbolas can touch their asymptotes at the edges of the graph.
questions.explanation: Asymptotes are never touched. The curve must approach asymptotes without reaching them, showing clear asymptotic behaviour.
questions.studyTip: Curve approaches but never reaches. Show the gap getting smaller.

questions.text: Graphs must show curves approaching but never intersecting asymptotes at limiting values.
questions.explanation: This asymptotic behaviour is essential. The graph should 'hug' the asymptote at the extremes.
questions.studyTip: Draw asymptotes as dashed lines first. Then sketch curve approaching them.

questions.text: Asymptotes should be drawn but don't need labels with their equations.
questions.explanation: Asymptotes must be labelled with equations: x = a for vertical, y = b for horizontal. Common error: swapping which is which.
questions.studyTip: Vertical asymptote: x = number. Horizontal asymptote: y = number.

questions.text: Each asymptote should be drawn as a dashed line and labelled with its equation.
questions.explanation: Labels show you understand what the asymptote represents. Don't swap x and y!
questions.studyTip: Common error: writing y = 2 for a vertical asymptote. That's wrong.

questions.text: The y-intercept (0, 5) can be labelled as (5, 0) since the key information is 5.
questions.explanation: (0, 5) and (5, 0) are completely different points. Getting coordinates in wrong order loses marks.
questions.studyTip: y-intercept: x = 0, so (0, y-value). x-intercept: y = 0, so (x-value, 0).

questions.text: Intercept coordinates must be written with x-coordinate first, y-coordinate second.
questions.explanation: Standard coordinate notation is (x, y). Swapping them is a common error that loses marks.
questions.studyTip: (x, y) always. The y-intercept is (0, something), not (something, 0).

questions.text: A truncus (reciprocal squared function) doesn't need to show symmetry.
questions.explanation: Functions like 1/x² are symmetric about their vertical asymptote. The graph must show this symmetry clearly.
questions.studyTip: Truncus is symmetric about the vertical asymptote. Both branches mirror each other.

questions.text: A truncus must display symmetry about its vertical asymptote.
questions.explanation: Both branches should be mirror images. Asymmetric truncus sketches lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Draw one branch, then reflect it for the other side.

questions.text: When sketching the derivative graph, you just need to get the general shape right.
questions.explanation: Derivative graphs must correspond to key features: zero gradient when original has turning points, positive/negative matching slopes.
questions.studyTip: Original has turning point → derivative crosses x-axis. Original increasing → derivative positive.

questions.text: The derivative graph must show zeros where the original function has turning points.
questions.explanation: f'(x) = 0 at turning points of f(x). Maximum/minimum gradient in f corresponds to turning points in f'.
questions.studyTip: Mark where f has turning points. Those are x-intercepts of f'.

questions.text: The graph of an inverse function can be sketched using any convenient method.
questions.explanation: The inverse function graph is a reflection of the original in the line y = x. This relationship must be evident.
questions.studyTip: f⁻¹(x) is f(x) reflected in y = x. Key points (a, b) become (b, a).

questions.text: Inverse function graphs should be symmetric with the original about the line y = x.
questions.explanation: Draw y = x first as a guide. Points (a, b) on f become (b, a) on f⁻¹.
questions.studyTip: Draw y = x. Your inverse graph should mirror the original across this line.

questions.text: Describing a transformation as 'stretch by factor 2' is always acceptable.
questions.explanation: Use correct terminology: 'dilation of factor 2 from the y-axis' or 'in the direction of the x-axis' or 'parallel to the x-axis'.
questions.studyTip: Know all three ways: 'from [axis]', 'in direction of [axis]', 'parallel to [axis]'.

questions.text: Transformations must be described using precise mathematical language from the study design.
questions.explanation: Transformation questions were not well answered because students used imprecise language.
questions.studyTip: Practice writing transformation descriptions. Use the exact terminology.

questions.text: A dilation factor of 2 'from the x-axis' stretches the graph vertically.
questions.explanation: Dilation from the x-axis means points move away from/towards the x-axis, which is vertical stretching.
questions.studyTip: From x-axis = vertical stretch. From y-axis = horizontal stretch.

questions.text: A dilation factor of 2 'from the y-axis' makes the graph twice as tall.
questions.explanation: Dilation from the y-axis stretches horizontally, making the graph twice as wide, not twice as tall.
questions.studyTip: From y-axis = horizontal. Points move left/right from the y-axis.

questions.text: In y = f(x - 2), the graph is translated 2 units to the left.
questions.explanation: y = f(x - 2) translates right. The negative inside means positive direction. Students often get this backwards.
questions.studyTip: f(x - a) moves RIGHT by a. f(x + a) moves LEFT by a. Counter-intuitive!

questions.text: A horizontal translation of +2 means the graph moves 2 units to the right.
questions.explanation: Positive horizontal direction is right. But watch the notation: f(x - 2) gives +2 translation.
questions.studyTip: Translation to right by 2 → f(x - 2). The signs swap!

questions.text: The order in which you perform transformations doesn't matter.
questions.explanation: Order matters when dilations and translations interact. Following the wrong sequence gives wrong results.
questions.studyTip: Generally: dilations before translations. Check your exam notes for the correct order.

questions.text: Some transformation sequences require operations in a specific order to get the correct result.
questions.explanation: A dilation then translation gives different results from translation then dilation.
questions.studyTip: Work from the function form. y = 2f(x - 1) means translate then dilate? Check carefully.

questions.text: Saying 'flip over the x-axis' is acceptable mathematical language for reflections.
questions.explanation: Use 'reflect in the y-axis' or 'reflection about the x-axis'. Casual language like 'flip' loses marks.
questions.studyTip: 'Reflect in the y-axis' not 'flip horizontally'. Use proper terms.

questions.text: Reflections should be described as 'reflect in the [axis name]'.
questions.explanation: The word 'in' is important. 'Reflect in the y-axis' is the standard mathematical phrasing.
questions.studyTip: y = -f(x) is reflection in x-axis. y = f(-x) is reflection in y-axis.

questions.text: For 'show that' questions, substituting and getting the right answer is enough.
questions.explanation: You must show logical progression from given information to the stated result. Just substituting values isn't sufficient.
questions.studyTip: Start from what's given. Show each step. End with the exact expression they want.

questions.text: 'Show that' questions require clear logical steps leading to the stated conclusion.
questions.explanation: Each step must follow logically from the previous. The assessor traces your reasoning.
questions.studyTip: Think: 'Because... therefore... hence...' Make the logic explicit.

questions.text: In 'show that' questions, obvious algebraic steps can be skipped.
questions.explanation: Even simple steps should be written. The purpose is demonstrating understanding, not just reaching the answer.
questions.studyTip: Write every line. What's obvious to you might not be to the assessor.

questions.text: Every algebraic manipulation in a 'show that' question should be explicitly written.
questions.explanation: Full working shows you understand the process. Skipped steps suggest you're copying the answer.
questions.studyTip: More steps = more evidence = more marks.

questions.text: 'Show that' questions are straightforward if you get the right answer.
questions.explanation: Getting the right answer isn't enough. Students struggle with these questions because they don't show adequate working.
questions.studyTip: Practise 'show that' questions specifically. They need a different approach.

questions.text: 'Show that' questions require dedicated practice to master the expected presentation.
questions.explanation: These questions are consistently poorly done. Practice showing logical, step-by-step working.
questions.studyTip: Do past 'show that' questions. Check examiner reports for expected responses.

questions.text: 'Verify' and 'show that' require exactly the same approach.
questions.explanation: 'Verify' typically means check given values work. 'Show that' requires deriving a result from scratch.
questions.studyTip: Verify = substitute and check. Show that = derive step by step.

questions.text: 'Verify' questions usually involve substituting given values to confirm they satisfy a condition.
questions.explanation: For 'verify', substitute the values and show the equation/condition is satisfied.
questions.studyTip: Verify P(2) = 0? Substitute x = 2 into P(x) and show you get 0.

questions.text: When a question says 'hence', you can solve it using any method you prefer.
questions.explanation: 'Hence' means use your previous result. Starting fresh ignores the intended approach and may lose marks.
questions.studyTip: 'Hence' = use what you just found. Don't start over.

questions.text: The word 'hence' indicates you must use your previous answer to solve the next part.
questions.explanation: It's guiding you to an efficient method. Your earlier work sets up the solution.
questions.studyTip: See 'hence'? Look back. How does your last answer help now?

questions.text: 'Find' and 'state' questions require the same amount of working.
questions.explanation: 'Find' usually requires calculation with working shown. 'State' may just need the answer read from context.
questions.studyTip: Find = calculate and show working. State = give the answer directly.

questions.text: 'Find' questions typically require calculation and working, while 'state' may just need an answer.
questions.explanation: Command words tell you what's expected. 'Find' signals more work is needed.
questions.studyTip: Pay attention to command words. They indicate expected depth of response.

questions.text: For binomial probability questions, you can just give the final numerical answer.
questions.explanation: You must identify and write down the n and p values, not just the answer. This shows understanding of the distribution.
questions.studyTip: Write: n = ..., p = ..., then P(X = k) = ... Show the setup.

questions.text: Binomial questions require stating the n and p values to demonstrate understanding.
questions.explanation: Writing X ~ Bin(n, p) or stating n = ..., p = ... shows you've identified the distribution correctly.
questions.studyTip: Always write: n = [number of trials], p = [probability of success].

questions.text: For continuous random variables, P(X = a) can be any small positive number.
questions.explanation: For continuous distributions, P(X = a) = 0 for any specific value a. Probability exists only for intervals.
questions.studyTip: Continuous variable: P(X = exact value) = 0. Always.

questions.text: For continuous random variables, P(X ≤ a) equals P(X < a) because P(X = a) = 0.
questions.explanation: Since single points have zero probability, including or excluding them doesn't change the result.
questions.studyTip: Continuous: P(X ≤ 5) = P(X < 5). The equality point doesn't matter.

questions.text: P(A|B) and P(A and B) represent the same probability.
questions.explanation: P(A|B) = P(A and B)/P(B). Conditional probability divides by the condition probability. They're different.
questions.studyTip: P(A|B) = P(A∩B)/P(B). Don't confuse 'and' with 'given'.

questions.text: Conditional probability P(A|B) requires dividing P(A and B) by P(B).
questions.explanation: Given B has occurred, we're restricted to that outcome space. P(A|B) = P(A∩B)/P(B).
questions.studyTip: 'Given B' means B definitely happened. Divide by P(B).

questions.text: P(X > 10) is the same as 1 - P(X ≤ 10) for a normal distribution.
questions.explanation: Since P(X = 10) = 0 for continuous distributions, P(X > 10) = P(X ≥ 10) = 1 - P(X ≤ 10) = 1 - P(X < 10).
questions.studyTip: For normal: P(X > a) = 1 - P(X ≤ a). Complements work cleanly.

questions.text: When using CAS for normal distributions, P(X ≥ 10) gives different results from P(X > 10).
questions.explanation: For continuous distributions these are equal. Your CAS may only have one option—that's fine.
questions.studyTip: Normal distribution: P(X ≥ a) = P(X > a). Don't stress about the symbol.

questions.text: If a question asks for standard deviation, giving variance is acceptable since you can convert.
questions.explanation: Give exactly what's asked. If it says standard deviation, don't give variance. Take the square root.
questions.studyTip: SD asked? Give SD. Variance asked? Give variance. Don't swap them.

questions.text: You must carefully check whether a question asks for variance or standard deviation.
questions.explanation: Students commonly calculate variance when standard deviation is asked. Read carefully and convert if needed.
questions.studyTip: SD = √Variance. If you have Var = 4, then SD = 2. Don't forget to root.

questions.text: To find k in a probability density function, you set f(x) = 1.
questions.explanation: The integral of f(x) over its domain equals 1, not f(x) itself. ∫f(x)dx = 1.
questions.studyTip: Total probability = 1 means ∫f(x)dx = 1, not f(x) = 1.

questions.text: For a PDF, the total area under the curve must equal 1: ∫f(x)dx = 1.
questions.explanation: This property lets you find unknown constants. Integrate f(x), set equal to 1, solve for k.
questions.studyTip: Finding k? Set up ∫f(x)dx = 1 and solve.

questions.text: The range of a function is always obvious from its equation.
questions.explanation: Range often requires analysing the function's behaviour—finding turning points, asymptotes, and endpoints.
questions.studyTip: Check: turning points, asymptotes, endpoint behaviour. These determine range.

questions.text: Finding the range may require identifying turning points and asymptotes.
questions.explanation: Minimum/maximum values from calculus, limiting behaviour from asymptotes—both inform the range.
questions.studyTip: Sketch or analyse. What y-values can the function actually reach?

questions.text: The interval where f'(x) > 0 uses round brackets, while f'(x) ≥ 0 uses square brackets.
questions.explanation: 'Strictly increasing' means f'(x) > 0, which requires round brackets to exclude endpoints where f'(x) = 0.
questions.studyTip: Strictly increasing → round brackets ( ). Including zeros → square brackets [ ].

questions.text: Strictly increasing intervals use round brackets because endpoints where f'(x) = 0 are excluded.
questions.explanation: At a turning point, f'(x) = 0, so the function is neither increasing nor decreasing there.
questions.studyTip: Strictly means 'no equals'. f'(x) > 0, so exclude points where f'(x) = 0.

questions.text: To find an inverse function, you just swap x and y and solve for y.
questions.explanation: You also need to state the domain of the inverse, which equals the range of the original function.
questions.studyTip: Inverse: swap, solve, AND state the domain.

questions.text: The domain of f⁻¹(x) equals the range of f(x).
questions.explanation: Inputs to the inverse are outputs of the original. Don't forget to state this domain.
questions.studyTip: Always give domain of inverse. It's the range of the original.

questions.text: The equation eˣ = -2 has a solution since we can take ln of both sides.
questions.explanation: eˣ > 0 for all x. The equation eˣ = -2 has no solution. Students must reject negative values.
questions.studyTip: eˣ is always positive. If you get eˣ = negative, no solution.

questions.text: When solving exponential equations, you must reject solutions where eˣ equals a negative number.
questions.explanation: eˣ only produces positive values. ln(negative) is undefined in real numbers.
questions.studyTip: Got eˣ = -3 as a possibility? Reject it immediately.

questions.text: When solving e²ˣ - 5eˣ + 6 = 0, you can substitute u = eˣ to make it quadratic.
questions.explanation: This substitution transforms to u² - 5u + 6 = 0. Solve for u, then solve eˣ = u.
questions.studyTip: Let u = eˣ. Then e²ˣ = u². Solve quadratic, then back-substitute.

questions.text: After substituting and solving a quadratic, all solutions for u give valid solutions for x.
questions.explanation: Only positive values of u give solutions, since eˣ > 0. Reject u ≤ 0.
questions.studyTip: u = eˣ means u must be positive. Reject non-positive solutions.

questions.text: Algebraic manipulation is always the best method for solving inequalities.
questions.explanation: When you've sketched a graph, use it! The graph visually shows where f(x) > g(x). Many students ignore their own graphs.
questions.studyTip: Just sketched a graph? Use it to read off inequality solutions.

questions.text: A graph sketch from an earlier part often helps solve inequalities in later parts.
questions.explanation: Questions are connected. Your graph shows where curves are above/below each other.
questions.studyTip: Look back at your graph. Where is one curve above the other?

questions.text: If your calculation gives an answer, you should trust it without checking.
questions.explanation: Check if answers make sense: probabilities between 0 and 1, positive areas, reasonable magnitudes.
questions.studyTip: Pause before final answer. Does this make sense in context?

questions.text: Checking whether your answer is reasonable can catch calculation errors.
questions.explanation: Probability of 2? Negative length? Area of 10⁶? These signal errors. Check and redo.
questions.studyTip: Quick sanity check: Is this answer physically/mathematically possible?

questions.text: CAS can do everything, so understanding the mathematics is less important in Exam 2.
questions.explanation: You must set up problems correctly and interpret output. CAS executes your plan—you still need to understand.
questions.studyTip: CAS is a tool. You need to know what to ask it and understand the answer.

questions.text: Effective CAS use includes knowing how to set up problems and interpret output.
questions.explanation: Strong students use CAS for calculation but understand the mathematics behind their work.
questions.studyTip: Know your CAS well. Practice different problem types before the exam.

concepts.title: Average value vs average rate of change

questions.text: Average value of a function and average rate of change are found using similar methods.
questions.explanation: Average value = (1/(b-a))∫f(x)dx. Average rate of change = [f(b)-f(a)]/(b-a). Completely different.
questions.studyTip: Average VALUE needs integration. Average RATE OF CHANGE is just slope.

questions.text: Average rate of change is [f(b) - f(a)]/(b - a), while average value involves integration.
questions.explanation: Students commonly confuse these. Rate of change = slope. Value = integral divided by interval length.
questions.studyTip: See 'average rate of change'? That's (y₂-y₁)/(x₂-x₁). No integral.

questions.text: Past exams are more useful than examiner reports for revision.
questions.explanation: Examiner reports show exactly where students went wrong and what assessors expect. Invaluable insights.
questions.studyTip: Do past exams, then read the reports. Learn from everyone's mistakes.

questions.text: Examiner reports reveal common errors and clarify expected response standards.
questions.explanation: Reports explain why marks were lost and show model solutions. Direct insight into assessment.
questions.studyTip: Reports tell you: 'Many students did X wrong.' Don't be one of them.
